isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - ROCKWELL TANDEM AXLE FORWARD REAR DRIVE UNITS - INSTALL - Adjusting the Preload on the Main Differential Side Bearings

svcproc.title: Adjusting the Preload on the Main Differential Side Bearings

svcprocinfo.para: Preload of Differential Side Bearings: 15 to 35 in-lbs. (1.7 to 3.9 Nm) Torque
Expansion Between Bearing Caps: 0.003-0.009 inch (0.080-0.228 mm) - 140 and 145 Series
Expansion Between Bearing Caps: 0.006 - .013 inch (0.152-0.330 mm) - 160 Series
Use the dial indicator or the large micrometer method for checking and adjusting the preload of the main differential side bearings.

step1.para: Attach a dial indicator on the mounting flange of the carrier.
Adjust the dial indicator so that the plunger or the pointer is against the back surface of the ring gear ( Figure 124).

caution.para: When you turn the adjusting rings, always use a tool that engages two or more opposite notches in the ring. A "T"-bar wrench can be used for this purpose. If the tool does not correctly fit into the notches, damage to the lugs will occur ( Figure 125).

figure.caption: Figure 125. Use Proper Tool for Turning Adjusting Rings

step1.para: Loosen the adjusting ring that is opposite the ring gear so that a small amount of end play shows on the dial indicator. Move the differential and the ring gear carefully to the left and right with pry bars while you read the dial indicator. Use one of the following methods:

note.para: On 160 Series axles, half of the bearing assembly extends out of the bearing cap and carrier.

step2.para: Use two pry bars that fit between the bearing adjusting rings and the ends of the differential case. The pry bars must not touch the differential bearings ( Figure 126).
Use two pry bars between the differential case or the ring gear and the carrier at locations other than those described in step A. The pry bars must not touch the differential bearings ( Figure 127).

figure.caption: Figure 126. Pry Bars Must Not Touch Bearings
Figure 127. Bars Must Not Touch Bearings

step1.para: Tighten the same bearing adjusting ring so that no end play shows on the dial indicator. Move the differential to the left and right as needed.
Tighten each bearing adjusting ring one notch from the zero end play measured in step 4. The side bearings of the differential now have a preload of 15 to 35 in-lbs. (1.7 to 3.9 Nm) ( Figure 128).
This will spread the legs 0.008-0.010 inch. It will put proper preload on the bearings when they are installed in the axle housing.

figure.caption: Figure 128. Tighten Bearing Adjusting Ring One Notch

step1.para: Continue by checking run-out of the ring gear.
Turn both adjusting rings hand-tight against the differential bearings.
Measure the distances X and Y between opposite surfaces of the bearing caps. Use a large micrometer of the correct size. Make a note of the measurement ( Figure 129 and Figure 130).

figure.caption: Figure 129. Measure Distances X and Y

caution.para: When you turn the adjusting rings, always use a tool that engages two or more opposite notches in the ring. A "T"-bar wrench can be used for this purpose. If the tool does not correctly fit into the notches, damage to the lugs will occur.

step1.para: Tighten each adjusting ring one notch ( Figure 125).
Measure the distances X and Y again. Compare the dimensions with the distances X and Y measured in step 2. The difference between the two dimensions is the amount the bearing caps have expanded.
Example: Distances X and Y before tightening adjusting rings = 15.315 inches (389 mm)
Distances X and Y after tightening adjusting rings = 15.324 in. (389.23 mm) 15.324 inches - 15.315 inches = 0.009 inch difference
If the dimension is at or within specifications, continue by checking runout of the ring gear. If the dimension is less than specifications, repeat Steps 3 and 4 as needed.
